## **A How-To Guide for Building a Text-To-Speech App on Linux**

### **What It Is**

DIY Linux Text-To-Speech, is a simple how-to guide to allow users of Linux based operating systems the ability to customize the visual and audio of a text-to-speech app for free.

One of the few areas where Linux based operating systems lack in comparison to other operating systems, is in their text-to-speech accessibility software. However, Linux operating systems tend to have a wide selection of interfaces and customization features. So this guide, will guide users to customize their experience; making it easier to simultaneously listen and read to text.

### **Step 1: Install eSpeak**

If your operating system has an [app store](https://rexradar.com/linux-app-stores/) , you can try using it to search for, and install eSpeak. But if you don't have an app store or eSpeak is not in your app store, you can either find the install file for your operating system [here](https://pkgs.org/search/?q=eSpeak) , or follow the below instructions use your terminal to install it. You can also watch [this short video](https://inv.riverside.rocks/watch?v=h3u7qOmWCzU) , demonstraiting how to install eSpeak via the terminal command line.

![](data:image/png;base64,)![](data:image/png;base64,)![](data:image/png;base64,)

Installing eSpeak With Your Terminal: As a first step, you will want to open the terminal on your computer. Most Linux operating systems will open the terminal with either the "ctrl + alt + t" or "[super_key](https://askubuntu.com/questions/705136/what-is-the-super-key-for-linux-shortcuts) + t" keyboard shortcut commands.

![](data:image/png;base64,)

Use the below "Copy" buttons to copy the installation text to your computer, or if that doesn't work, click and drag your mouse to select the text that corresponds to your operating system below. Then, right click with your mouse and select "Copy" from the menu.

After the text is copied, go back to the terminal, right click inside of it and select "Paste" from the menu, then press Enter.

- Debian Based Systems - Copy & Paste into terminal:
- Arch Based Systems - Copy & Paste into terminal:
- Fedora/RedHat Systems - Copy & Paste into terminal:
- openSUSE Systems - Copy & Paste into terminal:
- Solus OS Systems - Copy & Paste into terminal:

### **Step 2: Install Cool Retro Terminal**

If your operating system has an [app store](https://rexradar.com/linux-app-stores/) , you can try using it to search for, and install Cool Retro Terminal. But if you don't have an app store or Cool Retro Terminal is not in your app store, you can either find the install file for your operating system [here](https://pkgs.org/download/cool-retro-term) , or follow the below instructions use your terminal to install it.

![](data:image/png;base64,)![](data:image/png;base64,)

You can also watch [this video](https://inv.riverside.rocks/watch?v=z9DgGXz7jic) , demonstraiting how to install Cool Retro Terminal via the terminal command line. Either way, you will want to make sure you have "snapd" installed first, [instructions for that are here](https://snapcraft.io/docs/installing-snapd) .

![](data:image/png;base64,)![](data:image/png;base64,)

Installing Cool Retro Terminal With Your Terminal: As a first step, you will want to open the terminal on your computer. Most Linux operating systems will open the terminal with either the "ctrl + alt + t" or "[super_key](https://askubuntu.com/questions/705136/what-is-the-super-key-for-linux-shortcuts) + t" keyboard shortcut commands.

![](data:image/png;base64,)

Use the below "Copy" buttons to copy the installation text to your computer, or if that doesn't work, click and drag your mouse to select the text that corresponds to your operating system below. Then, right click with your mouse and select "Copy" from the menu.

After the text is copied, go back to the terminal, right click inside of it and select "Paste" from the menu, then press Enter.

- After you have [Snapd](https://snapcraft.io/docs/installing-snapd) Installed - Copy & Paste into terminal:

![](data:image/png;base64,)

Second Download & Unzip The App: Click the "Download" button located above this page, then go to your Downloads folder (or wherever your browser saves files to), and double-click the high-contrast-text-to-speech.zip file.

The file should open in an application that will have an option to extract the files. Go ahead and click extract and choose a location for the files. In some rare cases if double clicking doesn't work, you may need to download a compression app [like this](https://pkgs.org/download/engrampa) first.

![](data:image/png;base64,)

Running The App: You can now navigate to the DIY Linux Text-To-Speech folder that you extracted: open the folder, and then open theusr folder inside of that, and the bin folder inside of that. Finally double-click on the High_Contrast_Text_To_Speech file to run the app.

### **Step 3: Combine eSpeak & Cool Retro Terminal**

Now it's time to combine eSpeak and Cool Retro Terminal to get your text-to-speech app working!

Open the Cool Retro Terminal application. From here you can either, right click inside the application window, and select "View", and then "Show Menubar" from the menu, or you can press and hold the following keys on your keyboard: "Ctrl+Shift+M"

in the top menu bar select "edit", and then "settings", from the dropdown menu.

In the new "settings" pop-up menu, click on the "Advanced" tab at the top of the window, and click the checkbox to the left of the "Use custom command instead of shell at startup" text.Then in the empty text box just below that copy and paste (or type), this text into that box:

- Copy & Paste into Advanced Tab Text-box:

You will now need to completely close the Cool Retro Text To Speech app, and reopen it. This is called "restarting the application" and you will have to do it every time you make a change to the advanced tab text box.

Once you've restarted the app you can either type text, or copy and paste text, into the main window of Cool Retro Terminal and press enter. Your computer will then read aloud your text!

### **Step 4: Customize Audio & Visuals**

Customizing The Audio If you want to change the way the speaking voice sounds, you can navigate back to the text you put in the "Advanced" tab, and adjust the numbers next to the below values to make changes. It helps to have your computer's default terminal PUT LINK HERE open during this process as well.

\-s = Speed in words per minute, 80 to 450, default is 175

\-v = Voices, languages, and accents. Open your computer's default terminal and type "espeak --voices" to see a list of languages and accents that you can use to replace the "en-us" part of the command.

\-p = Pitch of the voice speaking, 0 to 99, default is 50

\-a = Amplitude / volume, 0 to 200, default is 100

There are many more changes you can make. To see a full list of them, type "espeak -h" into your computer's main terminal.

You can also use your computer's main terminal to [convert text documents to audio files](https://nealgodfrey.com/how-to-convert-text-document-to-speech-on-ubuntu-using-espeak/) of the text in the document spoken out loud.

![](data:image/png;base64,)

Customizing The VisualsYou can also make very big changes to the way the text looks when being read aloud. This can be especially helpful for individuals whom read more easily with different fonts, contrasts, text sizes, colors, etc.

To get a feel for some of these options, go back to the "Edit" Menu -> "Settings" window, and on the "General" tab, there is a "profile" box, with a list of pre-definied combinations of effects, colors, fonts, screen, and performance settings. You can select and use any of these, or if you prefer,you can adjust and/or turn on and off, values for effects, colors, fonts, screen, and performance, inside of each of the tabs of this "settings" window. You should be able to see the changes to the main Cool Retro Terminal window, as you adjust the values in the "Settings" window. Just make the changes to your liking and then close the "settings" window when done.
